fields.label_text:
ALTAR CROSS
Silver, parcel-gilt, with translucent enamel
South German; late 14th century (cross) and third quarter of 15th century (remainder)
From the Soltikoff collection
As a result of the separation in 1834 of Basle into city and Canton, the treasure of Basle Cathedral was divided into three lots. Two of these fell to the Canton and were auctioned in 1836; pieces were also sold from the lot which fell to the city of Basle.

RELIQUARY-CROSS FROM THE BASLE TREASURE
Silver, partly gilt, with translucent enamel and pearls
South German: the cross late 14th century; the base and the figures of St. John and the Virgin Mary, about 1475
The decoration of the late 15th century base includes the rich, late Gothic leaf work, seen on other objects in this case and in the engraving by Daniel Hopfer. The figures alongside are shown in drapery with angular, broken folds, similarly characteristic of German late Gothic. The new base was commissioned by the Basle Cathedral Chapter and paid for with money from the sale of indulgences (money paid to the Church by individuals hoping to gain salvation).

fields.descriptive_line: Silver parcel-gilt with enamels and pearls. Basel (?), the crucifix about 1350, the figures and base 1464-1474, Hans Rutenzwig or his workshop.

fields.physical_description: Gilded silver crucifix with cast figure of Christ, engraved and set with quatrefoils of enamel and pearls. The base raised, engraved, chased and partially gilded silver, with cast, chased and partially-gilt silver figures of the Virgin and Saint John the Evangelist. The back of the cross is formed by four hinged covers engraved with flowers.

fields.public_access_description:
This richly-gilded and enamelled crucifix was part of the treasury of Basel Cathedral, and was probably displayed with other precious objects on the high altar during important feast days in the Christian calendar. When not on display, it was stored securely out of sight in a cupboard. There is no record of the circumstances under which it entered the treasury of Basel Cathedral. The small figure of Christ suspended from a simple gold cross formed the original nucleus of this devotional object, which was made by an unknown goldsmith, probably in the Swiss city of Basel. A 1477 inventory of the Cathedral treasury describes 'a pretty silver cross with two figures, that is to say of Mary and John'. It is possible that the added foot and figures of the Virgin Mary and John the Evangelist were made in Basel by the goldsmith Hans Rutzenwig. The style of the figures recalls a standing figure of the Virgin Mary which he made in 1488 for a monstrance now in Porrentruy (Canton Jura). The inventory also records that the base of the cross was paid for by monies received for indulgences. Indulgences were documents sold by the Catholic Church which supposedly had the power to reduce the time spent by an individual in purgatory (the state suffered by a Christian soul before it entered heaven). Church reformers condemned this practice of speeding up salvation as dishonest and corrupt, but despite this it was a popular way for the church to generate revenue.

The compartments on the reverse of the cross, a later alteration, probably held relics, although there is no record to identify what they were. The worship of relics was also condemned by reformers as superstitious, but their circulation and sale provided another lucrative source of income for the Church. It is possible that once the cross had been altered to become a reliquary, it was taken on procession through the Cathedral on particular feast days.

fields.history_note:
The small figure of Christ suspended from a simple gold cross provided the original nucleus of this devotional object, which was made by an unknown goldsmith, probably in the Swiss city of Basel. There is no record of the circumstances under which it entered the treasury of Basel Cathedral. However, a 1477 Cathedral inventory describes 'a pretty silver cross with two figures, that is to say of Mary and John' ('ein hubsch silberin creutzlin cum duabus ymaginibus vid. Marie et Johannis' - cited in Burckhardt, <u>Der Basler Münsterschatz</u>, pp.233-8 and 361). The inventory also records that the figures (and, by implication, the base) were made during the tenure of the administrator and curate Heinrich Guglin. Guglin, who died in 1474, was in charge of the maintenance of the fabric of the Cathedral. The style of the figures recalls a standing figure of the Virgin Mary by Hans Rutenzwig, which forms part of a monstrance made in 1488 by the Basel goldsmith Jörg Schongauerand now in Porrentruy (Canton Jura). The attribution is strengthened by the fact that Rutenzwig was active in Basel during Guglin's administrative tenure. (On this, see Husband, <u>The Treasury of Basel Cathedral</u>, cat. no.14, p.60 and Meles, <u>Der Basler Münsterschatz</u>, cat. no.24, p.100.) 

In 1836 it was sold at auction in Liestal and acquired by the Basel goldsmith Johann Friedrich II, who later sold it. The cross and its base eventually entered the collection of Prince Peter Soltykoff, a collection dispersed at auction in Paris in 1861. It passed thence to the dealers Webb of London and in 1862 was acquired by the South Kensington Museum, London, later the Victoria and Albert Museum. See Husband, <u>The Treasury of Basel Cathedral</u>, cat. no.14, p.60. 

Basel Exhibition RF.96/1812

Historical significance: This type of crucifixion iconography, in which the cross bearing the crucified Christ is flanked by the figures of Christ's mother, Mary, and his disciple, John, is an ancient one dating back as early as the eighth century (see 'Archaeology of the Cross and Crucifix', in <u>The Catholic Encyclopedia</u>, www.newadvent.org). The presence of these two figures is explained by a passage in St John's Gospel, which records that Jesus's final command was to entrust John with the care of his ageing mother Mary (see John 19.25-27).

fields.historical_context_note:
The earliest surviving inventory of the contents of the Basel Cathedral treasury dates from 1477 (see Husband, <u>The Treasury of Basel Cathedral</u>, no.viii, p.44). It describes the precious crosses, reliquaries and monstrances that were displayed on the high altar of Basel Cathedral during solemn church festivals (such as Christmas and Easter). The inventory includes an entry for a cross which almost certainly corresponds to the one now in the V&A: 'a pretty silver cross with two figures, that is to say of Mary and John' (the original text cited in Burckhardt, <u>Der Basler Münsterschatz</u>, pp.233-8 and 361). When not on display as both tribute to, and demonstration of, the glory of God, the cross would have been locked away.
The inventory also records that the base of the cross was paid for by monies received for indulgences. Indulgences were documents sold by the Catholic Church which supposedly had the power to reduce the time spent by an individual in purgatory (the state suffered by a Christian soul before it entered heaven). Church reformers condemned this practice of speeding up salvation as dishonest and corrupt, but despite this it was a popular way for the church to generate revenue.
The compartments on the reverse of the cross, a later alteration, probably held relics, although there is no record to identify what they were. The worship of relics was also condemned by reformers as superstitious, but their circulation and sale provided another lucrative source of income for the Church. It is possible that once the cross had been altered to become a reliquary, it was taken carried through the Cathedral on procession during particular feast days (see Husband, <u>The Treasury of Basel Cathedral</u>, pp.20-22, for examples of treasury objects being treated in this way).
